Amy and Vince were paraded in the tabloids.

There was talk of them being secretly married. â€œI guess people are so anxious to have some news that they kind of create news where there necessarily isnâ€™t any,â€ she clarified.

But the religionâ€™s sex-shaming was in full gear. Amy Grant was now widely proclaimed throughout the Evangelical world as an â€˜adulteressâ€™, a â€˜slutâ€™, a â€˜whoreâ€™. Households were purged of her music. Her songs were dropped from church events.

Then a 38-year-old woman with hardly any theological training turned to her own religion, and took them to church.

â€œLetâ€™s get real,â€ she told CCM. â€œYou want to know what my real black ugly stuff is? Go look in the mirror and everything thatâ€™s black and ugly about you, itâ€™s the same about me. Thatâ€™s what Jesus died for.â€

How little we know about the private lives of other people.

Funny how that works? Iâ€™m going through old magazines and newspapers, noting details about the marriage of Amy Grant and Gary Chapman that somehow didnâ€™t make it into the church chatter.

In November 1997, Chapman did a profile for Texas Monthly to spice up his new career as a talk show host. He tells quite a tale.

Heâ€™d had a â€œdrug habitâ€ since age 20, doing â€œcocaine and marijuanaâ€ for as long as heâ€™d known his wife. â€œI had two distinctly different lives,â€ he says. â€œDifferent sets of friends, different likes, dislikes, actions, everything.â€

The reporter notes that Amy had let drop that â€œher wedding-night deflowering wasnâ€™t quite what she had hoped. In fact, she termed the first four months of connubial romps a â€˜yawn.â€™â€

I sit with the story of the most famous Christian marriage in the world: an addict husband, years of bad sex and counseling, living separately while sheâ€™s profoundly drawn to someone else.

And all the religion cared about was the rules about divorce.

The marriage was never much of one.

In 1979, Gary asked Amy out when she was a freshman at Furman University, already with one album. She said noâ€”repeatedly.

He was a singer-songwriter, and sheâ€™d be the most gifted interpreter of his music. His song â€œFatherâ€™s Eyesâ€ became the title track off her second album, and her first big hit.

It was like sheâ€™d stepped out of his creative imagination, the girl of his dreams. He kept calling her, sending tapes of his music. In the summer of 1980 he got a spot as her opening act.

â€œI guess I didnâ€™t realize he was courting,â€ she says. â€œI thought we were great friends, thatâ€™s all. He became a part of my family. They took him in because they thought he was just a companion to their little girl. It was pretty sneaky.â€

In June 1982, they married.

Years later she recalled that it â€œhad been rocky from the get-go. Iâ€™d been holding steady for 15 years in something that was not easy to hold steady.â€

Of course she was busy â€” being Amy Grant.

It was amazing that Amy Grant was even Christian.

Looking over her work in the 1980s, I realize how un-Christian she seems, in being dynamic and alive. In many churches, they were solemnly singing hundred year old hymns, as women werenâ€™t to speak, and their clothes were patrolled to make sure they were â€˜feminineâ€™.

Amyâ€™s clothing was, in fact, often masculine or androgynous. She was widely known, after all, as the â€œChristian answerâ€ to Madonna.

It was a bizarre spectacle: a Christian woman keeping up with big league pop stars. â€œI am really striving as an artist to be relevant and to communicate,â€ she said in 1985 to the Washington Post. â€œI donâ€™t want to cling to the past.â€

She was strangelyâ€¦sexual?

An interview in Rolling Stone startled her Christians fans. She was talking about a scene of skinny-dipping in the ocean. Sheâ€™d gotten into Bible study, she says, for the boys. But then, she adds, â€œI encountered the Bible in a way that really affected my life.â€

But sheâ€™d talk of her immersion in religion, curiously, with the language of sexual awakening. Sheâ€™d recall a scene in which sheâ€™d read the Song of Songs and gotten her theological bearings.

Ever light on moralizing, her idea of â€˜Jesusâ€™ seemed to be people getting along, a community having â€˜funâ€™ together. Her commentary, all along, could be so strange.

â€œI feel that a Christian young woman in the â€™80s is very sexual,â€ she said in a 1985 interview.

That was as un-Evangelical as could be.

The religion was gearing up for its â€œPurity Cultureâ€ phaseâ€”when it wasnâ€™t clear Amy was even much against premarital sex.

â€œIt seems to me that people who are most adamantly against premarital sex have experienced some kind of pain in their own lives,â€ she said in another 1985 interview.

Evangelicals loved her, but were apprehensive.

In 1985, Christianity Today sent a reporter to interview her pastor. â€œSheâ€™s not always wise in the way she says things,â€ the guy sighs. â€œShe doesnâ€™t want to be a sex symbol, but wants sex to be seen as a good thing, a godly thing.â€

But I think the reality is that Amyâ€™s sex talk was never too alarming because she was married.

There was talk that Gary was jealous of Amyâ€™s career.

Some of it is from Amy herself. â€œIt gets weird when Iâ€™m always in the forefront,â€ she said in 1986. When he got a record deal in 1986, she added, that â€œhas really been a boost for our relationship.â€

But then his album Everyday Man flopped. It just wasnâ€™t clear who he wasâ€”other than â€˜Mr. Amy Grantâ€™. The name was widely used, and deeply aggravated him. That wasnâ€™t the Evangelical male fantasy.

The Texas Monthly profile was a portrait of a Gary Chapman who spent years simmering that his wife was selling out stadiums, while he was with the band or the kids. He took to performing during her intermissions, but nobody was much paying attention.

Iâ€™m looking through fan memories.

Once, Gary was playing and the audience started booing, as he threw down his guitar and shouted, â€œYouâ€™re just jealous because Iâ€™m married to Amy Grant!â€ And stormed off stage.

The reviewer added: â€œThen he hit on my friend backstage when she was trying to interview him. Told her she was â€˜nice and curvy.â€™â€

Another memory, from a concert in the mid-80s. Amy came out at the end to take her bow. Gary came out to take her hand, and she snatched it away.

â€œI had a lot of reasons to be angry,â€ Gary recalled of the period. â€œI donâ€™t think any of them were valid, but they were to me at the time. I know that I felt overlooked.â€

Amy gave lip service to being a good Christian wife.

â€œIf I had my druthers,â€ she says, â€œI would be at home. It would suit me just being Mrs. Gary Chapman.â€

But she never took her husbandâ€™s name. There was never an â€˜Amy Chapmanâ€™. As hard as she tried, she kept being herselfâ€”sort of suggesting she wasnâ€™t exactly completely in love with Gary.

â€œMy personal feeling on love is,â€ she says in 1985, â€œif youâ€™re with somebody long enough and have an inclination toward one another, chances are youâ€™ll fall in love. I know there are people who meet for the first time and fall in love. A lot of times it comes from being stuck in a situation.â€

Gary and Amy went to get more counseling.

Amy recalled that a line from one counselor stuck in her mind:

â€œAmy, God made marriage for people. He didnâ€™t make people for marriage. He didnâ€™t create this institution so He could just plug people into it. He provided this so that people could enjoy each other to the fullest.â€

She was listening to her own music, and it all seemed different. Her Christian music didnâ€™t seem like her anymore. Even a song on House of Love, â€œSay Youâ€™ll Be Mine,â€ struck her as odd.

Sheâ€™ll recall thinking: â€œNo person really belongs to another, you know?â€

She decided she had to do it.

Sheâ€™d say later: â€œI just felt like I was really doing the unspeakable and at the same time feeling like I was coming back to life.â€

But it was a long process, and kicked off with a visit to Billy Graham. She arrived to play a Billy Graham crusade in Minneapolis in 1996, and felt she should tell him, as she put it, â€œthat my life was derailing.â€

She sat with Graham, the aging patriarch of Evangelicalism, and updated him on her decision. He seemed understanding? Amy recalls him saying: â€œGod is always at work in our lives, even when we take the long way home.â€

Not long afterward, Vince Gill announced he was separating from his wife.

Janis Gill knew of her husbandâ€™s affection for Amy, and didnâ€™t much appreciate it. Her 1996 song â€œI Know Who You Areâ€ is clearly a hostile portrait of Amy.

Vince quickly began dating another woman, the singer Bekka Bramlett, parading her in the tabloids. But was that a distraction from the idea of divorcing to marry Amy? In the theater of life.

Amy started work on her 1997 album, Behind the Eyes, which narrates the end of a marriage. Itâ€™d be called her â€˜divorce albumâ€™. With tracks like â€œI Will Be Your Friendâ€ and â€œTakes a Little Timeâ€ it can seem she was prepping her fans for the announcement â€” and teaching Christians how to uncouple?

After â€œa lengthy state of separation under the same roof,â€ she told Gary: â€œI believe and trust that Iâ€™ve been released from thisâ€¦â€ And he finally agreed to a divorce.

Amy knew her fans would try to cancel her.

I realize the story is that sheâ€™d known it was coming, and had no intention of playing the Christian role of â€˜shamedâ€™ woman. She mobilized her reputation and resources to ride out the storm.

Sheâ€™d describe her marriageâ€™s end as â€œa devastating personal failure.â€ Was that enough punishment? The religion had to think. Was it enough to gossip, malign her, keep her music off the radio, and not see her CDs in stores for awhile?

An unexpected scene reminded everyone of what Amy Grant had meant to them all. The Columbine school shooting on April 20, 1999 was a gaping wound in the nation and the world.

Two Evangelical figures were called to preside at the memorial.

Franklin Graham and Amy Grant. He lectured about â€˜sinâ€™. She sang her song â€œSomewhere Down the Road,â€ about meaning being elusive.

A father of one of the slain students, Grant recalled, told her, â€œIâ€™m just so glad that Iâ€™m getting to hear you sing today because my daughter really loved your music and it feels like a connection to her.â€

It felt, she recalled, like â€œthe lump in your throat is never going to go away.â€

She went back to her apology tour.

She explained her divorce in interview after interview. â€œI did the very best I could and I wound up here,â€ she says in one.

It remained a bumpy ride. In August 1999, when playing at the Gospel Music Associationâ€™s â€œMusic in the Rockiesâ€ in Colorado, she was singing a hymn, â€œâ€˜Tis So Sweet to Trust in Jesus,â€ and began weeping.

The audience watched in silence.

The divorce, sheâ€™d say, â€œleft me feeling like a stranger to myself and to God.â€

In her 2007 memoir, Mosaic: Pieces of My Life So Far, she refers to her divorce mostly in one passage. As it goes:

â€œWhen I chose to end my marriage to the father of my three older children, there was a time when I was too wrecked and too ashamed to pray with them at night. Deep in my own crisis of faith, I didnâ€™t know how to reconcile our broken home with the picture of God I had tried so hard to communicate to them over the years. I had no answers to their questions or mine â€” questions like, â€˜If God can do anything, then why didnâ€™t he fix our home?â€™ And so, I was silent.â€

Sheâ€™d note she â€œgot a good talking to from a lot of people.â€ But by the fall of 1999, when out on her Christmas tour, sheâ€™d speak of some personal healing happening.

â€œItâ€™s been a long time since I felt clear-headed, and I do now,â€ she says. â€œIt came at a really high price, but evidently, it was a price worth paying.â€

She came to her peace about the divorce. â€œJesus led by compassion,â€ she says in a 20021 interview. â€œNo one is ever changed because of judgment. No oneâ€™s ever healed through judgment.â€

Gary kept playing the role of cheated-on husband.

â€œIt was not Godâ€™s will that we divorced,â€ he told CCM in 2000. â€œFrom my vantage point, we had one â€˜irreconcilable differenceâ€™: I wanted her to stay, and she wanted to leave. Everything else, God could have reconciled.â€

Gary would push back at the idea that his cocaine use had led to the divorce. He gave it up in 1986, he emphasizes.

He doesnâ€™t say he wasnâ€™t doing anything else. In 2006, he was arrested driving drunk, and found with marijuana.

He re-married in 2006, and divorced the next year.

He remarried again in 2008â€”without much Evangelical commentary on any of that. His third wife explained she wasnâ€™t a gold digger, as widely supposed. Gary had, she noted, â€œlost it all in a real estate debacle.â€

In later interviews heâ€™d try to explain the sense of failure around his life. It started at age six, heâ€™d say. His pastor father gave a sermon from Matthew 25:1â€“13, on the ten virgins in a parable of Jesus. Five had enough oil, five didnâ€™t. He thought about it.

â€œSomehow it got in me in that I didnâ€™t have enough oil,â€ he says.

By the time he was in high school he was an alcoholic, and proceeded onto harder drugsâ€”ever in search of some substance to complete himself, while saying heâ€™d found it in God.

Gary is a major figure in Contemporary Christian Music. In retrospect, his cocaine use is a part of his career, and intrinsic to the genre itself. Where does anyone think they got all that enthusiasm?

Amy would work to calm down the religion.

â€œI am not an advocate for divorce,â€ she tells the New York Times in 2002. â€œThe Bible clearly says God hates divorce. I donâ€™t ever want to justify that.â€

She adds: â€œThereâ€™s a grieving side of divorce that never goes away. Thereâ€™s a loss of personal history, and thereâ€™s a sense of personal shame. But Iâ€™m really so glad to be where I am right now.â€

That wasnâ€™t the contrition Evangelicals wanted to see. The wish for it became insistent. Finally, Christian media decided it was time for her to repent. In 2002, CCM sent a reporter, Matthew Paul Turner, to interview Amy Grant about her new album of hymns.

He arrived at her house with his editorâ€™s ultimatum: â€œIf she doesnâ€™t make a public apology, then sheâ€™s not going in the magazine.â€

Turner explained to Amy that he had to ask her to apologize.

She thought about it.

â€œDo I feel sorry because my life hasnâ€™t turned out like I thought it would,â€ she replied, â€œand because of that, I have fans that feel disappointed or betrayed? Sure. I never make a decision without considering how it will affect the people in my life. Sometimes I do that to a fault.â€

She thought some more, and added: â€œThe hardest part for me, Matthew, was forgiving myself. But once you do, you canâ€™t keep going back. You accept the grace and live.â€

Turner wrote the story he wanted to write.

Later he saw that CCM had run a re-written version. Somehow, Amy was apologizingâ€”using, he said, â€œfabricatedâ€ quotes.
